rewritten_query: What are the steps to create a machine learning model for my purpose?
agent_response:
Yes, you can create a machine learning model in IBM Watson Knowledge Studio. Here are the general steps to create a machine learning model:

1. Create a workspace: A workspace is a single project that contains the artifacts and resources needed to build a machine learning model. You can create a new workspace by logging in as a Knowledge Studio administrator, clicking on Create Workspace, giving it a name, identifying the language of the documents in your workspace, and clicking Create.
2. Create a type system: A type system defines the entity types and relation types that human annotators can apply when annotating text. You can upload or create the type system in the workspace and work with subject matter experts for your domain to define it.
3. Add documents for annotation: You can create a corpus by uploading sample documents that are representative of your domain content into the workspace. You can then partition the corpus into document sets, specify the percentage of documents that are shared among all document sets, and assign the document sets to human annotators.
4. Annotate documents: The human annotators will annotate the text according to the type system that you have defined.
5. Train the machine learning model: Once the documents have been annotated, you can train the machine learning model. The model process manager will use the annotated text to learn how to identify entities, coreferences, and relationships of interest in new documents.
6. Deploy the machine learning model: Once the model has been trained, you can deploy it as an API that can be used to predict the outcome with test data.

For more details, you can refer to the IBM Watson Knowledge Studio documentation on creating a machine learning model.

original_query: Speaking about bots again, can they get private information from the user
extracted_sentences: Can you summarize the differences between good bots and bad bots?
Good bots and bad bots behave differently on the internet.
Good bots perform helpful services, such as customer service chatbots, search engine crawlers, and performance monitoring bots.
They follow the rules outlined in a website's robots.txt file.
On the other hand, bad bots misuse online products or services, ranging from malicious to simply annoying behaviors.
Examples of bad bots include those that break into user accounts to steal data or buy concert tickets online to assist scalpers.
Malicious bots don't follow the honor system of checking a website's robots.txt file before accessing the website.
What are the features in the CIS bot?
IBM Cloud® Internet Services (CIS) bot includes features such as JavaScript detections, which use Google's Picasso fingerprinting technique to gather general data about the machines reaching CIS.
This technique helps classify traffic as automated or human by factoring Picasso results into bot scores.
BotScoreSrc: Not Computed and a score of 0 are relevant to Picasso JavaScript Fingerprinting requests, which are exempt from being blocked by any firewall rules.
JavaScript is only injected in response to requests for HTML pages or page views, excluding AJAX calls, and the Picasso script is roughly 70 KB with an execution time varying by device.

The snippets of JavaScript will contain a source pointing to the challenge platform with paths that start with /cdn-cgi/challenge-platform/.... JavaScript detections are automatically enabled for No-cost Trial plans and optional for all other plans.
A firewall rule with the field cf.bot_management.js_detection.passed can be created to ensure that visitors have previously run and passed JavaScript detections.
How does CIS manage bots?
IBM Cloud® Internet Services (CIS) manages bots by collecting data from requests flowing through its network daily.
With this data, powered by Cloudflare's machine learning and behavior analysis, CIS can identify likely bot activity.
CIS provides information on how to allow or disallow specific bot traffic using Firewall Rules.

CIS Bot Management uses various detection mechanisms, including a machine learning model, heuristics engine, behavioral analysis, verified bots, JS fingerprinting, and Google's Picasso fingerprinting technique.
These methods help classify traffic as automated or human by factoring Picasso results into bot scores.
How can I update machine leaning models?
To update machine learning models in the context of bot management in IBM Cloud® Internet Services (CIS), you can enable auto-updates for the machine learning model.

Here are the steps:

1.
Log in to the CIS and select your account and domain.
Go to Security > Bots.
Select Configure Bot Management.
Enable auto-updates to the machine learning model.
Enabling auto-updates immediately upgrades you to the latest version of the machine learning model.
You can toggle the button off within 24 hours to revert to the previous version.
To make changes after 24 hours, you need to contact support.
If you are on an older machine learning model, you'll see a score change to requests scored by the machine learning source instantly.
If you are already on the latest model, the changes show only after a new machine learning model becomes the global default.
You will be notified prior to a new machine learning model becoming the global default.
By not updating to the latest version, you will be using a machine learning model that is no longer maintained or monitored by the engineering team.
As internet traffic changes and new trends evolve, the scoring accuracy of older versions can degrade.

rewritten_query: Can bots access private user information?
agent_response: Bots, whether good or bad, can only access information that is willingly provided to them or is publicly available. They do not have the ability to access private information from users without explicit permission or without it being shared in the course of the conversation. However, it is important to be cautious when sharing sensitive information with bots, as they are automated systems that could potentially misuse the information if it falls into the wrong hands.

rewritten_query: Could you explain what a secret is in this context?
agent_response: A secret is a piece of sensitive information, such as an API key, password, or any type of credential used to access a confidential system. Secrets are used to authenticate to protected resources as you build your applications, allowing entities to communicate and perform actions on a service in a secure manner. They typically include passwords, API keys, long-lived authentication tokens, SSH keys, encryption keys, and other private keys. Application providers should ensure that secrets are generated and stored securely, with access control measures and minimal exposure to people and machines. Solutions like IBM Cloud Secrets Manager and Hyper Protect Crypto Services can help protect application secrets and encryption keys.

rewritten_query: Can you explain how to protect my privacy?
agent_response:
Protecting your privacy involves several steps, including:

1. Being cautious about the personal information you share online, especially on social media platforms.
2. Using strong, unique passwords for each of your online accounts and enabling multi-factor authentication where possible.
3. Regularly updating and patching your devices and software to protect against known vulnerabilities.
4. Being wary of suspicious emails, messages, and links, and not clicking on them.
5. Using a Virtual Private Network (VPN) to encrypt your internet connection and hide your online activity.
6. Using security tools and services, such as IBM Cloud Secrets Manager and Hyper Protect Crypto Services, to protect your sensitive information and encryption keys.
7. Avoiding the storage of personal data as metadata for your keys and avoiding the entry of personally identifiable information (PII) when adding keys to a service.
8. Ensuring that key material meets specific requirements, such as being base64-encoded and a certain length, depending on the service you are using.
9. Regularly reviewing and updating your privacy settings on the websites and apps you use.
10. Being aware of your rights as a data subject, including the right to access, rectify, erase, object to the processing, and data portability, and exercising these rights when necessary.

rewritten_query: Could you clarify what you mean by 'worker nodes' in this context?
agent_response: Worker nodes are virtual machines that are managed by your Kubernetes cluster in the IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service. These worker nodes are dedicated to you and are not shared with other IBM customers, although the underlying hardware is shared. They provide the necessary resources to run and manage your applications and services. Worker nodes include various components such as the kubelet, kube-proxy, and container runtime. You can manage worker nodes through the automation tools provided by IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service, like the API, CLI, or console. Worker nodes are created in a VPC subnet and can be used to create Kubernetes LoadBalancer services for exposing your apps. Calico is used as the cluster networking policy fabric.

rewritten_query: Could you explain what VPC clusters are?
agent_response: VPC clusters are a type of Kubernetes cluster in the IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service that are created within a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC). A VPC is a network infrastructure service that provides an isolated environment for your workloads to run within the public cloud. VPC clusters use VPC subnets to provide private IP addresses for worker nodes and load balancer services. They can be used to separate clusters for different departments or to have different clusters host separate microservices that need to communicate with each other. By default, a VPC cluster is created with a public and a private cloud service endpoint.

rewritten_query: Can you guide me on how to create a cluster?
agent_response:
To create a cluster in IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service, you can follow the steps provided in the document. First, you need to set up your account to create clusters. Then, depending on the type of infrastructure you prefer, you can create a cluster on VPC or Classic infrastructure.

For Kubernetes on VPC infrastructure, you need to click Standard tier cluster, create a VPC with a unique name and resource group, attach a Public Gateway to each of the subnets, and then click Create cluster.

For Kubernetes on Classic infrastructure, you need to choose a resource group, uncheck all zones except one, scale down to 1 Worker node per zone, choose the smallest Worker Pool flavor, enter a Cluster name, and then click Create.

Once the cluster is up and running, you can perform various administration tasks such as spreading worker nodes, deploying an app, setting up a private registry, setting up the cluster autoscaler, and controlling who can create pods in the cluster. Additionally, you can also perform network configuration steps for your cluster setup.

However, the document does not provide specific instructions on how to create a cluster from the UI. It mainly focuses on how to decide on the cluster setup, create a cluster with infrastructure, network, and availability setups, and then perform various administration tasks and network configuration steps. If you are looking for a fast way to create a cluster from the UI, you can try out IBM Cloud Schematics templates.

Worker nodes are virtual machines that are managed by your Kubernetes cluster in the IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service.
These worker nodes are dedicated to you and are not shared with other IBM customers, although the underlying hardware is shared.
They provide the necessary resources to run and manage your applications and services.
Worker nodes include various components such as the kubelet, kube-proxy, and container runtime.
You can manage worker nodes through the automation tools provided by IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service, like the API, CLI, or console.
Worker nodes are created in a VPC subnet and can be used to create Kubernetes LoadBalancer services for exposing your apps.

what are VPC clusters?
VPC clusters are a type of Kubernetes cluster in the IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service that are created within a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC).
A VPC is a network infrastructure service that provides an isolated environment for your workloads to run within the public cloud.
VPC clusters use VPC subnets to provide private IP addresses for worker nodes and load balancer services.
They can be used to separate clusters for different departments or to have different clusters host separate microservices that need to communicate with each other.
By default, a VPC cluster is created with a public and a private cloud service endpoint.
How to create a cluster.
To create a cluster in IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service, you can follow the steps provided in the document.
First, you need to set up your account to create clusters.
Then, depending on the type of infrastructure you prefer, you can create a cluster on VPC or Classic infrastructure.

For Kubernetes on VPC infrastructure, you need to click Standard tier cluster, create a VPC with a unique name and resource group, attach a Public Gateway to each of the subnets, and then click Create cluster.

For Kubernetes on Classic infrastructure, you need to choose a resource group, uncheck all zones except one, scale down to 1 Worker node per zone, choose the smallest Worker Pool flavor, enter a Cluster name, and then click Create.

Once the cluster is up and running, you can perform various administration tasks such as spreading worker nodes, deploying an app, setting up a private registry, setting up the cluster autoscaler, and controlling who can create pods in the cluster.
Additionally, you can also perform network configuration steps for your cluster setup.

rewritten_query: Could you explain what Data Encryption is?
agent_response: Data Encryption is a method of encoding data to ensure that it can only be accessed by authorized parties. In the context of the provided document, Data Encryption refers to the encryption of data on a field-level basis using the Data Security Broker software. This encryption is performed using a Data Security Broker Manager to enumerate the data schema and enable an encryption key mapping. Data Encryption helps protect sensitive information from unauthorized access and is one of the four main modes of data protection services supported by the Data Security Broker.

rewritten_query: Is data encryption the same as data backup and disaster recovery?
agent_response:
No, data encryption, data backup, and disaster recovery are not the same. 

Data Encryption is the process of converting data into a code to prevent unauthorized access.

Data Backup is the process of creating copies of data to protect it from loss or damage.

Disaster Recovery is the process of restoring data and systems after a catastrophic event.

While data encryption can be a part of a data backup and disaster recovery strategy, it serves a different purpose, which is to protect data from unauthorized access.

rewritten_query: Can you provide more information about VPC in this context?
agent_response:
Based on the documents you provided, I can give you an overview of Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) in the context of IBM Cloud.

IBM Cloud VPC is a virtual network that is linked to your customer account, providing cloud security, scalability, and fine-grained control over your virtual infrastructure and network traffic segmentation. VPCs can be deployed in a single region and span multiple zones within that region.

Subnets in your VPC can connect to the public internet through an optional public gateway, and you can assign floating IP addresses to virtual server instances to enable them to be reachable from the internet. Subnets within the VPC offer private connectivity and can talk to each other over a private link through the implicit router, without setting up routes.

Regions represent the geographic area in which a VPC is deployed and contain multiple zones, while zones are abstractions that refer to the physical data center hosting compute, network, and storage resources, with related cooling and power. Zones are isolated from each other for fault tolerance, reduced latency, and a default address prefix specifying the address range for subnet creation.

VPCs can encapsulate corporate divisions or collections of microservices owned by a DevSecOps team and can be connected to on-premises enterprises and other VPCs, potentially requiring traffic routing through centralized firewall-gateway appliances.

The documents also mention some updates, like the expansion of file storage general purpose 3 IOPS/GB profile, the introduction of placement groups (Beta), UI enhancements, and Application Load Balancer (ALB) support for cookie-based session persistence.

For specific information on how cloud computing security protocols evolve over time and their implications for restoring volumes from backup snapshots in IBM Cloud VPC, I recommend checking the official IBM Cloud VPC documentation or contacting IBM support directly.

Based on the provided document, it does not contain specific information about how cloud computing security protocols evolve over time.
However, I can provide some general insights on this topic.
As cloud computing technology advances, so do security protocols to address new threats and vulnerabilities.
This can include updates to encryption standards, access management policies, and network security measures.
Regarding the restoration of volumes from backup snapshots in IBM Cloud VPC, the provided documents mention some relevant points.
For instance, when restoring a volume from a backup snapshot, the data is copied from IBM Cloud Object Storage to Block Storage for VPC, which might result in degraded performance initially.

Also, there's an option for cross-regional copy of backup snapshots, which can be used in disaster recovery scenarios when you need to turn on your virtual server instance and data volumes in a different region.
However, the documents do not provide specific information on how these restoration processes might be impacted by the evolution of security protocols in IBM Cloud VPC.
For the most accurate and up-to-date information, I would recommend checking the official IBM Cloud VPC documentation or contacting IBM support directly.
What is Data Encryption?
Data Encryption is a method of encoding data to ensure that it can only be accessed by authorized parties.
In the context of the provided document, Data Encryption refers to the encryption of data on a field-level basis using the Data Security Broker software.
This encryption is performed using a Data Security Broker Manager to enumerate the data schema and enable an encryption key mapping.
Data Encryption helps protect sensitive information from unauthorized access and is one of the four main modes of data protection services supported by the Data Security Broker.
It is the same as data backup and disaster recovery, right?
No, data encryption, data backup, and disaster recovery are not the same.
Data Encryption is the process of converting data into a code to prevent unauthorized access.
Data Backup is the process of creating copies of data to protect it from loss or damage.
Disaster Recovery is the process of restoring data and systems after a catastrophic event.
While data encryption can be a part of a data backup and disaster recovery strategy, it serves a different purpose, which is to protect data from unauthorized access.

rewritten_query: What are the different types of clouds?
agent_response:
Based on the provided document, there are three different types of clouds available: public, private, and hybrid. 

- A public cloud includes a shared set of resources that are provisioned to allow access to a company's resources. It is hosted in a multi-tenant environment on a virtual server, and it can be accessed from anywhere.

- A private cloud includes resources that are provisioned to allow access to a company's resources. It is hosted on dedicated hardware, such as a bare metal server, and either onsite at the company's office (or across offices) or by a cloud provider. A private cloud can be accessed from anywhere.

- A hybrid cloud includes resources that combine the aspects of both public and private clouds. It is hosted both onsite at a company's office (or across offices) and by a cloud provider. A hybrid cloud can be accessed from anywhere.

For more specific information about the cloud types in the context of IBM Cloud, you may want to refer to the official IBM Cloud documentation or contact IBM support directly.

IBM Cloud VPC is a virtual network that is linked to your customer account, providing cloud security, scalability, and fine-grained control over your virtual infrastructure and network traffic segmentation.
VPCs can be deployed in a single region and span multiple zones within that region.

Subnets in your VPC can connect to the public internet through an optional public gateway, and you can assign floating IP addresses to virtual server instances to enable them to be reachable from the internet.
Subnets within the VPC offer private connectivity and can talk to each other over a private link through the implicit router, without setting up routes.

Regions represent the geographic area in which a VPC is deployed and contain multiple zones, while zones are abstractions that refer to the physical data center hosting compute, network, and storage resources, with related cooling and power.
Zones are isolated from each other for fault tolerance, reduced latency, and a default address prefix specifying the address range for subnet creation.

rewritten_query: What are the benefits of data encryption?
agent_response:
The benefits of using cloud computing services, such as those provided by IBM Cloud, include:

1. Flexibility: Cloud computing allows you to scale your resources up or down based on your needs, providing flexibility and cost savings.
2. Cost-effectiveness: Cloud services can help reduce capital expenditures, as you don't need to invest in hardware or maintain on-site infrastructure. Instead, you pay for the resources you use.
3. Accessibility: Cloud computing enables access to your applications and data from any location with an internet connection, allowing for remote work and collaboration.
4. Security: Reputable cloud providers invest heavily in security measures and follow industry best practices to protect their infrastructure and customer data.
5. Reliability: Cloud services typically offer uptime guarantees and redundancy, ensuring your applications and data are available when you need them.

For specific benefits related to the IBM Cloud data protection services, you may refer to the provided document or contact IBM support directly.

Regarding the benefits of envelope encryption, the provided document highlights the following:

1. Customer-managed encryption keys: You can provision root keys to protect the security of your encrypted data in the cloud and manage data encryption keys (DEKs) provisioned in IBM Cloud data services.
2. Confidentiality and integrity protection: Hyper Protect Crypto Services uses the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) algorithm in Cipher Blocker Chaining (CBC) mode to create and protect keys, ensuring only you have access.
3. Cryptographic shredding of data: If your organization detects a security issue or no longer needs a set of data, you can choose to shred the data permanently from the cloud.
4. Delegated user access control: Hyper Protect Crypto Services supports a centralized access control system to enable granular access for your keys.

For more information about envelope encryption or other IBM Cloud services, consult the provided document or contact IBM support directly.

rewritten_query: How can I estimate my costs?
agent_response:
Based on the provided document, you can estimate your costs using the IBM Cloud cost estimator tool. Here are the steps to create a new estimate:

1. In the IBM Cloud console, go to the Cost estimator icon.
2. Click "Create new estimate."
3. Enter a name and description for the estimate.
4. Click "Create."
5. From here, you are directed to the estimate details page. Click "Go to catalog" to add products to the estimate.
6. Select the product that you are interested in.
7. Depending on the product, an interim informational page might be displayed. For example, if you select Bare Metal Servers, an informational page that describes various features is displayed. Click "Continue."
8. Select your pricing plan and enter other configuration details if needed. Then, click "Add to estimate."
9. Enter your estimated usage, and click "Calculate Cost." You can adjust the estimated usage and recalculate the cost to see how different usage levels affect the overall cost.

Pricing can vary by region, so if you are estimating costs for a different location or currency, you might have to select the appropriate currency on the order summary page for the product or change the currency on your account.

It is important to note that the cost estimate does not include all resources, usage, licenses, fees, discounts, or taxes. The estimate is subject to change as the architecture is customized and deployed. Additionally, some charges, such as the costs for your underlying infrastructure, might not be reflected in the estimate.

rewritten_query: Are there different types of charges I am charged?
agent_response:
Yes, there are different types of charges you might encounter on your IBM Cloud invoice. The document outlines three major types of usage charges:

1. **In Advance**: These are recurring infrastructure monthly usage charges, such as charges for the month of March, that you incur until you cancel the service.
2. **In Arrears**: These are usage-based charges from the previous month. In the provided example, these charges are presented in a 672 hrs \* .066 format.

Additionally, you might have one-time charges, such as fees for specific services or resources. The document also mentions that some services might offer free allocations, which would be applied to the account level and not the organization level.

rewritten_query: Could you explain the differences among Fixed, Metered, Tiered, and Reserved, as those terms were used in the context of billing plans?
agent_response:
Sure, I'd be happy to explain the differences between Fixed, Metered, Tiered, and Reserved charges:

1. **Fixed**: Fixed charges are based on an agreed-upon monthly charge that does not change based on usage. For example, if you purchase an additional bare metal server, virtual server, or storage resource after the start of the monthly billing period, the cost of the resource for the first month is prorated based on the number of days remaining in the billing period.
2. **Metered**: Metered charges are usage-based pricing models in which you pay for what you consume. For example, with the Push service, any usage over the free monthly allowance is charged on a per-usage basis.
3. **Tiered**: Tiered charges are similar to metered charges, but they offer discounted charges in tiers with larger consumption. Tiered pricing is often offered in simple, graduated, or block models.
4. **Reserved**: Reserved charges are based on a long-term commitment for a service, so you can get a discounted price. With a reserved plan, you get a dedicated service instance that is easy to set up, deploy, and deliver in the public IBM Cloud environment. Services such as Db2 on Cloud offer reserved plans.

It's important to note that these charging models can apply to different types of resources and services on IBM Cloud.

rewritten_query: I'd like to change my pricing plan and check my usage consumption.
agent_response:
To update your pricing plan, you can follow the instructions in the document for Updating your service plan. This process can be completed using the UI, API, or CLI.

To view your usage, you can check your usage dashboard in the IBM Cloud console. The dashboard displays your products and resources with Monthly, Hourly, or a combination of both tags to signify how often charges are updated.

The Monthly tag signifies that resources within your account have a fixed cost, while the Hourly tag signifies that resources within your account have variable costs. These charges are updated daily for hourly resources and prorated in proportion to how many days are left in the month for monthly fixed costs.

Additionally, you can monitor your usage with Lite plans, which are structured as a free quota. Lite plans might operate for a specific time period, such as a month, or on a one-off usage basis. The following list provides some examples of Lite plan quotas:

* Maximum number of registered devices
* Maximum number of application bindings

It's important to note that once you exceed the quota for your Lite plan, you will be charged for additional usage.

1.

are there different types of charges I am charged?
Yes, there are different types of charges you might encounter on your IBM Cloud invoice.

The document outlines three major types of usage charges:

1.
**In Advance**: These are recurring infrastructure monthly usage charges, such as charges for the month of March, that you incur until you cancel the service.
**In Arrears**: These are usage-based charges from the previous month.
In the provided example, these charges are presented in a 672 hrs \* .066 format.
Additionally, you might have one-time charges, such as fees for specific services or resources.
The document also mentions that some services might offer free allocations, which would be applied to the account level and not the organization level.
can you tell me the difference among Fixed, Metered, Tiered, and Reserved?
**Fixed**: Fixed charges are based on an agreed-upon monthly charge that does not change based on usage.

For example, if you purchase an additional bare metal server, virtual server, or storage resource after the start of the monthly billing period, the cost of the resource for the first month is prorated based on the number of days remaining in the billing period.
**Metered**: Metered charges are usage-based pricing models in which you pay for what you consume.
For example, with the Push service, any usage over the free monthly allowance is charged on a per-usage basis.
**Tiered**: Tiered charges are similar to metered charges, but they offer discounted charges in tiers with larger consumption.
Tiered pricing is often offered in simple, graduated, or block models.
**Reserved**: Reserved charges are based on a long-term commitment for a service, so you can get a discounted price.
With a reserved plan, you get a dedicated service instance that is easy to set up, deploy, and deliver in the public IBM Cloud environment.
Services such as Db2 on Cloud offer reserved plans.
It's important to note that these charging models can apply to different types of resources and services on IBM Cloud.

rewritten_query: What is the process for managing my payments?
agent_response:
The process of managing your payments on IBM Cloud involves several steps. First, you must ensure that you have the necessary permissions by being assigned the operator role or higher on the billing account management service. Then, depending on your account type, you can manage your payment methods using the Payments page in the IBM Cloud console or by going to IBM Billing. For Pay-As-You-Go and Subscription accounts, a valid credit card is required, and updates to your payment details are typically applied within 24 hours. If you need help with payment-related issues, you can contact IBM Cloud Support.

If you're using a new US-based Pay-As-You-Go account with credit card billing, you can add a new credit card in the Monthly Payment Method form on the Payments page. For all other accounts, you can remove a credit card and switch to a different payment method by clicking Pay with Other > Submit change request. If you manage your payment method on a separate billing platform, you can remove your credit card by going to IBM Billing.

When you request to change your payment method, a support case is created automatically, and you can check the status of your request by going to the Manage cases page in the IBM Cloud console. Additionally, if you have a Pay-As-You-Go account that's billed in US dollars, you can view your invoice in the IBM Cloud console by going to Manage > Billing and usage, > and clicking Invoices. If you own one of the following accounts, you can view your invoice on the IBM Invoices website, which is linked from the Invoices page in the console.

For more information about managing your payments, you can refer to the document "Managing your payment method outside of the console."

rewritten_query: How can I view my invoices and current status?
agent_response:
To view your invoices and their status, you can follow these steps:

1. Go to the IBM Cloud console.
2. Click on "Manage" in the top navigation bar.
3. Select "Billing and usage" from the dropdown menu.
4. Click on "Invoices" in the submenu.

From there, you can view your invoices and their status. If your invoice status is "Invoiced," it means that the latest invoice has been sent to you. If the status is "Paid," it means that the payment for the charges on your latest invoice has been received. If the status is "Unpaid," it means that the charges on your latest invoice have not been paid. If the status is "Pending," it means that your payment for your latest charges has not been applied due to a payment processing error.

Additionally, you can view and download your invoice by clicking the "Download" icon next to each invoice. If your invoices are managed through the IBM Invoices website, you can see the invoice status by checking if the status is "Settled."

It's important to note that turning a resource "off" doesn't cancel the resource in your account. You will receive invoices for resources in your account until you cancel them. For more information, see [Cancelling your billing items](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/billing-usage?topic=billing-usage-cancel-billing-items).

are there different types of charges I am charged?
Yes, there are different types of charges you might encounter on your IBM Cloud invoice.

The document outlines three major types of usage charges:

1.
**In Advance**: These are recurring infrastructure monthly usage charges, such as charges for the month of March, that you incur until you cancel the service.
**In Arrears**: These are usage-based charges from the previous month.

can you tell me the difference among Fixed, Metered, Tiered, and Reserved?
**Fixed**: Fixed charges are based on an agreed-upon monthly charge that does not change based on usage.

For example, if you purchase an additional bare metal server, virtual server, or storage resource after the start of the monthly billing period, the cost of the resource for the first month is prorated based on the number of days remaining in the billing period.
**Metered**: Metered charges are usage-based pricing models in which you pay for what you consume.
For example, with the Push service, any usage over the free monthly allowance is charged on a per-usage basis.
**Tiered**: Tiered charges are similar to metered charges, but they offer discounted charges in tiers with larger consumption.
Tiered pricing is often offered in simple, graduated, or block models.
**Reserved**: Reserved charges are based on a long-term commitment for a service, so you can get a discounted price.
With a reserved plan, you get a dedicated service instance that is easy to set up, deploy, and deliver in the public IBM Cloud environment.
Services such as Db2 on Cloud offer reserved plans.
It's important to note that these charging models can apply to different types of resources and services on IBM Cloud.

rewritten_query: I can't apply a subscription code, why is that?
agent_response:
Based on the provided document, there are a few reasons why you might not be able to apply a subscription code. Here are some possible reasons:

1. **Expired code**: The subscription code may have already expired. In this case, you would need to contact the person who provided the code for help with reissuing a new code.
2. **Insufficient access**: To apply any code, you must have an Editor role or higher on all account management services. If you don't have access to apply subscription codes, the account owner or administrator can provide access.
3. **Child account in an enterprise**: If your account is a child account on the enterprise, you can't apply subscription codes. Subscription codes must be applied at the enterprise level. In this case, you would need to contact the owner or the administrator of the enterprise to add the subscription code.

If none of these reasons apply to your situation, I would recommend contacting IBM Cloud Support for further assistance.

how can I estimate my costs?
Based on the provided document, you can estimate your costs using the IBM Cloud cost estimator tool.

Here are the steps to create a new estimate:

1.
In the IBM Cloud console, go to the Cost estimator icon.
Click "Create new estimate."
Enter a name and description for the estimate.
From here, you are directed to the estimate details page.
Click "Go to catalog" to add products to the estimate.
Select the product that you are interested in.
Depending on the product, an interim informational page might be displayed.
For example, if you select Bare Metal Servers, an informational page that describes various features is displayed.
Select your pricing plan and enter other configuration details if needed.
Then, click "Add to estimate."
Enter your estimated usage, and click "Calculate Cost."
You can adjust the estimated usage and recalculate the cost to see how different usage levels affect the overall cost.

Pricing can vary by region, so if you are estimating costs for a different location or currency, you might have to select the appropriate currency on the order summary page for the product or change the currency on your account.
It is important to note that the cost estimate does not include all resources, usage, licenses, fees, discounts, or taxes.
The estimate is subject to change as the architecture is customized and deployed.
Additionally, some charges, such as the costs for your underlying infrastructure, might not be reflected in the estimate.
are there different types of charges I am charged?
Yes, there are different types of charges you might encounter on your IBM Cloud invoice.

The document outlines three major types of usage charges:

1.
**In Advance**: These are recurring infrastructure monthly usage charges, such as charges for the month of March, that you incur until you cancel the service.
**In Arrears**: These are usage-based charges from the previous month.
In the provided example, these charges are presented in a 672 hrs \* .066 format.
Additionally, you might have one-time charges, such as fees for specific services or resources.
The document also mentions that some services might offer free allocations, which would be applied to the account level and not the organization level.
can you tell me the difference among Fixed, Metered, Tiered, and Reserved?
**Fixed**: Fixed charges are based on an agreed-upon monthly charge that does not change based on usage.

For example, if you purchase an additional bare metal server, virtual server, or storage resource after the start of the monthly billing period, the cost of the resource for the first month is prorated based on the number of days remaining in the billing period.
**Metered**: Metered charges are usage-based pricing models in which you pay for what you consume.
For example, with the Push service, any usage over the free monthly allowance is charged on a per-usage basis.
**Tiered**: Tiered charges are similar to metered charges, but they offer discounted charges in tiers with larger consumption.
Tiered pricing is often offered in simple, graduated, or block models.
**Reserved**: Reserved charges are based on a long-term commitment for a service, so you can get a discounted price.
With a reserved plan, you get a dedicated service instance that is easy to set up, deploy, and deliver in the public IBM Cloud environment.
Services such as Db2 on Cloud offer reserved plans.
It's important to note that these charging models can apply to different types of resources and services on IBM Cloud.
I want to update my pricing plan and view my usage
To update your pricing plan, you can follow the instructions in the document for Updating your service plan.
This process can be completed using the UI, API, or CLI.
To view your usage, you can check your usage dashboard in the IBM Cloud console.
The dashboard displays your products and resources with Monthly, Hourly, or a combination of both tags to signify how often charges are updated.
The Monthly tag signifies that resources within your account have a fixed cost, while the Hourly tag signifies that resources within your account have variable costs.
These charges are updated daily for hourly resources and prorated in proportion to how many days are left in the month for monthly fixed costs.
Additionally, you can monitor your usage with Lite plans, which are structured as a free quota.
Lite plans might operate for a specific time period, such as a month, or on a one-off usage basis.

The following list provides some examples of Lite plan quotas:

* Maximum number of registered devices
* Maximum number of application bindings

It's important to note that once you exceed the quota for your Lite plan, you will be charged for additional usage.
am I charged for those support costs as well?
The document does not provide specific information about support costs being included in the IBM Cloud invoice.
However, it does mention that you can track your monthly support costs in the IBM Cloud console by going to Manage > Billing and usage, and selecting Support costs.
It is recommended to review the support plan details or contact IBM Cloud Sales for more information about support cost billing.
what is the process of managing my payments?
The process of managing your payments on IBM Cloud involves several steps.
First, you must ensure that you have the necessary permissions by being assigned the operator role or higher on the billing account management service.
Then, depending on your account type, you can manage your payment methods using the Payments page in the IBM Cloud console or by going to IBM Billing.
For Pay-As-You-Go and Subscription accounts, a valid credit card is required, and updates to your payment details are typically applied within 24 hours.
If you need help with payment-related issues, you can contact IBM Cloud Support.
If you're using a new US-based Pay-As-You-Go account with credit card billing, you can add a new credit card in the Monthly Payment Method form on the Payments page.
For all other accounts, you can remove a credit card and switch to a different payment method by clicking Pay with Other > Submit change request.
If you manage your payment method on a separate billing platform, you can remove your credit card by going to IBM Billing.
When you request to change your payment method, a support case is created automatically, and you can check the status of your request by going to the Manage cases page in the IBM Cloud console.
Additionally, if you have a Pay-As-You-Go account that's billed in US dollars, you can view your invoice in the IBM Cloud console by going to Manage > Billing and usage, > and clicking Invoices.
If you own one of the following accounts, you can view your invoice on the IBM Invoices website, which is linked from the Invoices page in the console.
For more information about managing your payments, you can refer to the document "Managing your payment method outside of the console."
view my invoices and status

To view your invoices and their status, you can follow these steps:

1.
Go to the IBM Cloud console.
Click on "Manage" in the top navigation bar.
Select "Billing and usage" from the dropdown menu.
Click on "Invoices" in the submenu.
From there, you can view your invoices and their status.
If your invoice status is "Invoiced," it means that the latest invoice has been sent to you.
If the status is "Paid," it means that the payment for the charges on your latest invoice has been received.
If the status is "Unpaid," it means that the charges on your latest invoice have not been paid.
If the status is "Pending," it means that your payment for your latest charges has not been applied due to a payment processing error.
Additionally, you can view and download your invoice by clicking the "Download" icon next to each invoice.
If your invoices are managed through the IBM Invoices website, you can see the invoice status by checking if the status is "Settled."
It's important to note that turning a resource "off" doesn't cancel the resource in your account.
You will receive invoices for resources in your account until you cancel them.
For more information, see [Cancelling your billing items](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/billing-usage?topic=billing-usage-cancel-billing-items).
Why do you think I can not apply a subscription code?
Based on the provided document, there are a few reasons why you might not be able to apply a subscription code.

Here are some possible reasons:

1.
**Expired code**: The subscription code may have already expired.
In this case, you would need to contact the person who provided the code for help with reissuing a new code.
**Insufficient access**: To apply any code, you must have an Editor role or higher on all account management services.
If you don't have access to apply subscription codes, the account owner or administrator can provide access.
**Child account in an enterprise**: If your account is a child account on the enterprise, you can't apply subscription codes.
Subscription codes must be applied at the enterprise level.
In this case, you would need to contact the owner or the administrator of the enterprise to add the subscription code.
If none of these reasons apply to your situation, I would recommend contacting IBM Cloud Support for further assistance.

rewritten_query: I've encountered issues when trying to update my credit card, as it keeps showing errors.
agent_response:
If you're experiencing issues with updating your credit card, there are a few things you can try. First, ensure that the information you're entering, such as the card number and expiration date, are correct. If the problem persists, try using a different web browser or clear your browser's cache and cookies. If the issue still isn't resolved, you can contact IBM Cloud Support for further assistance. They can help troubleshoot the problem and provide a solution.

According to the provided document, the error you're encountering when updating your credit card may be due to incorrect card information or a network issue affecting the loading of the Credit Card information section of the form. If none of the suggested troubleshooting steps work, contacting IBM Cloud Support is recommended.

rewritten_query: I'm getting an error: 'Could not place order. Problem authorizing the credit card. We are unable to process your request: Transaction Rejected'.
agent_response: This error message indicates that there was a problem authorizing your credit card, and the transaction was rejected by your credit card issuer. This could be due to various reasons such as insufficient funds, reaching the credit limit, or the card being expired or deactivated. To resolve this issue, I would recommend contacting your credit card issuer for more information. They can provide you with specific details regarding why the transaction was rejected and guide you on how to resolve the issue. Once the issue has been resolved with your credit card issuer, you can try updating your credit card information again.

rewritten_query: Could you tell me what constitutes a strong password?
agent_response: A strong password is one that is difficult for others to guess, either manually or through automated means. It should have a certain level of complexity, such as a minimum length and the inclusion of various character types. The exact requirements for a strong password can vary, but some common practices include having a minimum length of 8 characters, containing at least one number, one lowercase letter, and one capital letter, and avoiding the use of common words or phrases. Additionally, using a unique character and avoiding the use of personal information, such as usernames or email addresses, can also strengthen a password. The specific requirements for a strong password can be configured in the App ID dashboard or using the management APIs.

rewritten_query: What is the retention time for the conversations?
agent_response: The retention time for conversations in Watson Assistant depends on your service plan. For the Enterprise with Data Isolation and Premium (legacy) plans, chat message retention is last 90 days. For the Enterprise and Plus plans, chat message retention is last 30 days. Additionally, the retention period of an object can only be extended, not decreased. The retention expansion value can be set in various ways, including adding a specified amount of time to the current value or setting a new retention expiry date for the object.

rewritten_query: Can you delete conversations?
agent_response: Yes, you can delete conversations in Watson Assistant. To delete messages using customer\_id values, refer to the Information security topic in the Watson Assistant documentation. It is important to note that the delete feature will remove messages for one or more individuals, and the Overview metrics will no longer reflect those deleted messages. Also, the customer\_id string cannot include the semicolon (;) or equal sign (=) characters, and you are responsible for ensuring that each Customer ID parameter is unique across your customers.

original_query: What are the different types of dialog nodes?
rewritten_query: What are the different types of dialog nodes?
agent_response:
Based on the documents provided, there are at least two types of dialog nodes:

1. A node that conditions on an intent value: This type of node is useful to capture questions about a certain topic and then, in the root response, ask a follow-up question that is addressed by the child nodes. 

2. A node with slots: This type of node conditions on an intent value and defines a set of slots. Each slot asks a question to elicit the answer from the user and looks for a specific entity value in the user's reply to the prompt, which it then saves in a slot context variable. This type of node is useful for collecting details you might need to perform a transaction on the user's behalf.

Additionally, there are response types that can be used in dialog nodes, such as Connect to human agent, Image, Option, and Pause.

agent_response: Intents are a way to categorize what a user wants to do in a conversation. They represent the user's goal or objective in a conversation and are typically defined by a set of example user inputs. For example, an intent for ordering a pizza might include example inputs such as "I want to order a pizza" or "Can I get a pizza delivered to my house?". Intents help the system understand the user's intent and provide an appropriate response.

rewritten_query: Could you explain how to create a dialog node?
agent_response:
To create an intent, you can follow these steps:

1. Go to the Intents tab in your dialog skill.
2. Click on the Create Intent button.
3. Provide a name for your intent.
4. Add example user inputs that represent the intent. These examples help the system understand what the user might say to express this intent.
5. Save the intent.

After creating the intent, you can add a dialog node that conditions on this intent. When the user's input matches the intent, the dialog node will be processed.

original_query: Are dialogue skills necessary?
extracted_sentences: What are the different types of dialog nodes?

Based on the documents provided, there are at least two types of dialog nodes:

1.

A node that conditions on an intent value: This type of node is useful to capture questions about a certain topic and then, in the root response, ask a follow-up question that is addressed by the child nodes.
A node with slots: This type of node conditions on an intent value and defines a set of slots.
Each slot asks a question to elicit the answer from the user and looks for a specific entity value in the user's reply to the prompt, which it then saves in a slot context variable.
This type of node is useful for collecting details you might need to perform a transaction on the user's behalf.
Additionally, there are response types that can be used in dialog nodes, such as Connect to human agent, Image, Option, and Pause.
Whatar are intents?
Intents are a way to categorize what a user wants to do in a conversation.
They represent the user's goal or objective in a conversation and are typically defined by a set of example user inputs.
For example, an intent for ordering a pizza might include example inputs such as "I want to order a pizza" or "Can I get a pizza delivered to my house?".
Intents help the system understand the user's intent and provide an appropriate response.
How is it created?

To create an intent, you can follow these steps:

1.
Go to the Intents tab in your dialog skill.
Click on the Create Intent button.
Provide a name for your intent.
Add example user inputs that represent the intent.
These examples help the system understand what the user might say to express this intent.
Save the intent.
After creating the intent, you can add a dialog node that conditions on this intent.
When the user's input matches the intent, the dialog node will be processed.
Are those the only steps?
The steps provided are the basic steps for creating an intent.
However, there might be additional steps or options depending on the platform or tool you are using to build your dialog skill.
It's always a good idea to refer to the specific documentation of the platform or tool for more detailed instructions.

rewritten_query: Are dialogue skills necessary?
agent_response:
Dialog skills are not absolutely necessary, but they can be very useful in creating conversational experiences for users. Dialog skills allow you to define a conversational flow, including intents, dialog nodes, and responses, which can help guide the user through a conversation and provide appropriate responses based on the user's input.

If you have a simple use case where you only need to provide a few predefined responses to user inputs, then you may not need a dialog skill. However, for more complex conversational experiences, where you need to capture user input, interpret it, and provide dynamic responses based on the user's input, a dialog skill can be very helpful.

Ultimately, whether or not you need a dialog skill depends on your specific use case and the complexity of the conversational experience you want to create.

rewritten_query: Could you explain the difference between a dialog node and a dialog skill?
agent_response: A dialog node is a component of a dialog skill. A dialog skill is a container for the natural language processing training data and artifacts that enable an assistant to understand user questions and respond to them. A dialog node is a unit within a dialog skill that defines a part of the conversation flow. It contains conditions based on user intents or other contextual information, and defines the assistant's responses or actions based on those conditions. So, while a dialog skill is the container for the overall conversation model, a dialog node is a specific building block within that model.

rewritten_query: Are there any advantages to adding a skill to my assistant?
agent_response:
Yes, adding a skill to your assistant can provide several advantages. Custom skills allow you to tailor the assistant's responses to better suit your specific needs and use cases. 

For instance, conversational skills help you address common questions or requests that your customers typically have. You provide information about the subjects or tasks that your users need help with, and the product dynamically builds a machine learning model that is tailored to understand the same and similar user requests.

A search skill, on the other hand, enables your assistant to search for and return passages from existing self-service content, providing more detailed and accurate answers to user queries.

Furthermore, an actions skill offers a simple interface where anyone can build a conversational flow for your assistant to follow, automating complex processes and improving the overall user experience.

In summary, adding skills to your assistant can help you create more engaging, accurate, and personalized conversational experiences for your users.

rewritten_query: Could you help me find or learn about a skill?
agent_response: A search skill is a type of custom skill that enables your assistant to search for and return passages from existing self-service content, providing more detailed and accurate answers to user queries. It uses IBM Watson® Discovery for IBM Cloud Pak® for Data to crawl, convert, and normalize your unstructured data, and then enrich it with data analysis and cognitive intuition to make it easier to find and retrieve meaningful information. You can add a search skill to your assistant to prevent it from having to say things like, I'm sorry. I can't help you with that. Instead, the assistant can query existing company documents or data to see whether any useful information can be found and shared with the customer.

original_query: How can I update the cluster master?
rewritten_query: How can I update the cluster master?
agent_response: To update the cluster master, you can use the `ibmcloud ks cluster master update` command. If you don't want to update the master to the default major.minor version during the update, you can include the `--version` option and specify the latest patch version that is available for the major.minor version that you want. You can list available versions by running `ibmcloud ks versions`. Please note that you cannot interact with your cluster while it is updating and you cannot roll back a cluster to a previous version after the update process takes place. Therefore, it is recommended to use a test cluster and follow the instructions to address potential issues before you update your production master. Also, remember that after the master update is complete, you can update your worker nodes.

rewritten_query: You mentioned CIS Kubernetes Benchmark, is this related to the update process or are you asking for information on that specifically?
agent_response:
The CIS Kubernetes Benchmark is a framework of specific steps to configure Kubernetes more securely and with standards that are commensurate to various industry regulations. The benchmark is published by the Center for Internet Security (CIS).

You can find CIS Kubernetes Benchmark results for different versions of Kubernetes in the IBM Cloud documentation. The results for Kubernetes version 1.21 can be found in the document titled "[Version 1.21 CIS Kubernetes Benchmark](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-cis-benchmark121)". The results for versions 1.26, 1.27, and other versions are also available in similar documents. These results can help you understand how specific versions of your Red Hat® OpenShift® on IBM Cloud® clusters meet the CIS Kubernetes Benchmark.

If you're a security administrator or auditor, you might want to compare your company's internal standards and external regulatory requirements with the CIS Kubernetes Benchmark. The benchmark recommendations are provided by the Center for Internet Security, not by IBM.

For more information or help understanding the benchmark, you can refer to the "Using the benchmark" section in the IBM Cloud documentation. If you're using Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud, you can also compare the default configuration of a cluster that runs a Kubernetes version that is part of a supported Red Hat OpenShift version against the benchmark.

Additionally, IBM has provided a guide on how to [run the CIS Kubernetes benchmark tests on your own worker nodes](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-cis-benchmarkcis-worker-test).

rewritten_query: What are some recommended practices for IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service?
agent_response:
Here are some recommended practices for IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service:

1. Use the IBM version of community Kubernetes or Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud as your container management platform.
2. Set up a Continuous Integration (CI) toolchain for security and compliance-related best practices in DevSecOps.
3. Use a free cluster for testing out Kubernetes deployments and getting familiar with the IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service API, CLI, and console tools.
4. After testing, copy your configuration files and redeploy them to a standard cluster.
5. Take advantage of the service's intelligent scheduling, self-healing, horizontal scaling, service discovery, load balancing, automated rollouts and rollbacks, and secret and configuration management features.
6. Utilize the advanced capabilities around simplified cluster management, container security and isolation policies, and integrated operational tools for consistency in deployment.
7. Scan the container image for security vulnerabilities and add a Docker signature upon successful completion.
8. Automatically configure access permissions for target cluster deployment by using API tokens that can be revoked.

Additionally, you can follow the CIS Kubernetes Benchmark for configuration steps to secure your Kubernetes cluster. You can also refer to the IBM Cloud documentation for CIS Kubernetes Benchmark results for different versions of Kubernetes.

Please note that you can use IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service in various regions around the world, including but not limited to the USA, Sydney, Australia, Frankfurt, Germany, London, United Kingdom, Tokyo, Japan, Osaka, Japan, Dallas, US, Washington DC, US, Sao Paulo, and Toronto, CA.

agent_response: Kubernetes is an open-source platform for managing containerized workloads and services across multiple hosts. It offers management tools for deploying, automating, monitoring, and scaling containerized applications with minimal manual intervention. It groups containers that make up your microservice into pods, which are logical units for easy management and discovery. These pods run on compute hosts that are managed in a Kubernetes cluster, which is portable, extensible, and self-healing in case of failures. extracted_sentences: How can I update the cluster master?
To update the cluster master, you can use the `ibmcloud ks cluster master update` command.

If you don't want to update the master to the default major.minor version during the update, you can include the `--version` option and specify the latest patch version that is available for the major.minor version that you want.
You can list available versions by running `ibmcloud ks versions`.
Please note that you cannot interact with your cluster while it is updating and you cannot roll back a cluster to a previous version after the update process takes place.
Therefore, it is recommended to use a test cluster and follow the instructions to address potential issues before you update your production master.
Also, remember that after the master update is complete, you can update your worker nodes.
CIS Kubernetes Benchmark
The CIS Kubernetes Benchmark is a framework of specific steps to configure Kubernetes more securely and with standards that are commensurate to various industry regulations.
The benchmark is published by the Center for Internet Security (CIS).
You can find CIS Kubernetes Benchmark results for different versions of Kubernetes in the IBM Cloud documentation.
The results for Kubernetes version 1.21 can be found in the document titled "[Version 1.21 CIS Kubernetes Benchmark](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-cis-benchmark121)".
The results for versions 1.26, 1.27, and other versions are also available in similar documents.
These results can help you understand how specific versions of your Red Hat® OpenShift® on IBM Cloud® clusters meet the CIS Kubernetes Benchmark.
If you're a security administrator or auditor, you might want to compare your company's internal standards and external regulatory requirements with the CIS Kubernetes Benchmark.
The benchmark recommendations are provided by the Center for Internet Security, not by IBM.
For more information or help understanding the benchmark, you can refer to the "Using the benchmark" section in the IBM Cloud documentation.

If you're using Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud, you can also compare the default configuration of a cluster that runs a Kubernetes version that is part of a supported Red Hat OpenShift version against the benchmark.

Additionally, IBM has provided a guide on how to [run the CIS Kubernetes benchmark tests on your own worker nodes](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-cis-benchmarkcis-worker-test).
Can I use IBM Cloud® Kubernetes Service clusters only in USA?

No, IBM Cloud® Kubernetes Service clusters can be used in various regions including but not limited to Sydney, Australia (au-syd), Frankfurt, Germany (eu-de), London, United Kingdom (eu-gb), Tokyo, Japan (jp-tok), Osaka, Japan (jp-osa), Dallas, US (us-south), Washington DC, US (us-east), Sao Paulo (br-sao), and Toronto, CA (ca-tor).
For a full list of available regions, you can refer to the IBM Cloud documentation.

rewritten_query: How does IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service work and why should I use it?
agent_response:
IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service is a managed Kubernetes offering provided by IBM that allows you to quickly and efficiently deploy and manage containerized applications. It provides powerful tools, an intuitive user experience, and built-in security for rapid delivery of apps that can be bound to various cloud services related to IBM Watson, AI, IoT, DevOps, security, and data analytics.

As a certified Kubernetes provider, IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service offers features such as intelligent scheduling, self-healing, horizontal scaling, service discovery and load balancing, automated rollouts and rollbacks, and secret and configuration management. It also provides advanced capabilities around simplified cluster management, container security and isolation policies, the ability to design your own cluster, and integrated operational tools for consistency in deployment.

You can use IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service in various regions around the world, including but not limited to the USA, Sydney, Australia, Frankfurt, Germany, London, United Kingdom, Tokyo, Japan, Osaka, Japan, Dallas, US, Washington DC, US, Sao Paulo, and Toronto, CA.

The service is ideal for testing out Kubernetes deployments and getting familiar with the IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service API, CLI, and console tools. It can also be used to scan container images for security vulnerabilities, automatically configure access permissions for target cluster deployment, and follow the CIS Kubernetes Benchmark for configuration steps to secure your Kubernetes cluster.

In summary, IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service provides a powerful and easy-to-use platform for deploying and managing containerized applications, with advanced features and security capabilities to help you deliver your apps quickly and efficiently.

rewritten_query: What options and access should be set to secure my cluster?
agent_response:
To secure your cluster in IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service, you can use built-in security features to protect various components such as the Kubernetes API server, etcd data store, worker node, network, storage, images, and deployments against malicious attacks. You can also leverage built-in logging and monitoring tools to detect malicious attacks and suspicious usage patterns.

In terms of access policies, IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service uses Cloud Identity and Access Management (IAM) to grant access to cluster resources. You can grant access through IAM platform access roles and Kubernetes role-based access control (RBAC) policies through IAM service access roles. The access policies that you assign users vary depending on what you want your users to be able to do. For example, you might assign the Editor role to a user who needs to create and update resources in the cluster, or the Viewer role to a user who only needs to view resources.

For more information about types of access policies, see [Pick the correct access policy and role for your users](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-access-overviewaccess_roles). For steps to assign policies, see [Granting users access to your cluster through IBM Cloud IAM](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-userschecking-perms).

It is important to only grant the minimum access necessary for users to perform their tasks, and to regularly review and revoke access as needed. Additionally, you can follow the CIS Kubernetes Benchmark for configuration steps to secure your Kubernetes cluster. You can find more information in the IBM Cloud documentation.

IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service is a managed Kubernetes offering provided by IBM that allows you to quickly and efficiently deploy and manage containerized applications.

It provides powerful tools, an intuitive user experience, and built-in security for rapid delivery of apps that can be bound to various cloud services related to IBM Watson, AI, IoT, DevOps, security, and data analytics.

As a certified Kubernetes provider, IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service offers features such as intelligent scheduling, self-healing, horizontal scaling, service discovery and load balancing, automated rollouts and rollbacks, and secret and configuration management.

It also provides advanced capabilities around simplified cluster management, container security and isolation policies, the ability to design your own cluster, and integrated operational tools for consistency in deployment.

You can use IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service in various regions around the world, including but not limited to the USA, Sydney, Australia, Frankfurt, Germany, London, United Kingdom, Tokyo, Japan, Osaka, Japan, Dallas, US, Washington DC, US, Sao Paulo, and Toronto, CA.
The service is ideal for testing out Kubernetes deployments and getting familiar with the IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service API, CLI, and console tools.

It can also be used to scan container images for security vulnerabilities, automatically configure access permissions for target cluster deployment, and follow the CIS Kubernetes Benchmark for configuration steps to secure your Kubernetes cluster.

In summary, IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service provides a powerful and easy-to-use platform for deploying and managing containerized applications, with advanced features and security capabilities to help you deliver your apps quickly and efficiently.
what options and access should I give out to secure my cluster?

To secure your cluster in IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service, you can use built-in security features to protect various components such as the Kubernetes API server, etcd data store, worker node, network, storage, images, and deployments against malicious attacks.
You can also leverage built-in logging and monitoring tools to detect malicious attacks and suspicious usage patterns.
In terms of access policies, IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service uses Cloud Identity and Access Management (IAM) to grant access to cluster resources.
You can grant access through IAM platform access roles and Kubernetes role-based access control (RBAC) policies through IAM service access roles.
The access policies that you assign users vary depending on what you want your users to be able to do.
For example, you might assign the Editor role to a user who needs to create and update resources in the cluster, or the Viewer role to a user who only needs to view resources.
For more information about types of access policies, see [Pick the correct access policy and role for your users](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-access-overviewaccess_roles).
For steps to assign policies, see [Granting users access to your cluster through IBM Cloud IAM](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/containers?topic=containers-userschecking-perms).
It is important to only grant the minimum access necessary for users to perform their tasks, and to regularly review and revoke access as needed.
You can find more information in the IBM Cloud documentation.

rewritten_query: Can I get some information about service support in case I run into some issues?
agent_response:
Yes, of course! If you encounter any issues while using IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service, you can access support through the IBM Cloud Support Center. To create a support case, you must have a Pay-As-You-Go or Subscription account and be assigned at least the editor role on the Support Center account management service. You can then follow these steps:

1. Click the Help icon from the console menu bar.
2. From the Contact support section, click Create a case.
3. Select All products.
4. Select IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service as the topic and click Next.
5. Complete the required fields.

Remember to not include any personal information, sensitive data, or device or service credentials in case responses. For more information about opening an IBM support ticket, or about support levels and ticket severities, see [Contacting support](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/get-support?topic=get-support-support-case-severitysupport-case-severity).

For assistance with third-party services or open source or community services, support is provided by the service provider or open source community, respectively. IBM can share analysis with third-party service providers or refer you to the community or forum for assistance.

If you're experiencing issues with Partner Center, you can also create a support case specifically for that. More information about creating a support case for Partner Center issues can be found in the provided document.

rewritten_query: Is it possible to store an image or PDF alongside a document in IBM Cloudant?
agent_response:
IBM Cloudant allows you to store attachments alongside documents, which can be used for storing small icons, images, PDFs, and other static assets. However, you should be aware that IBM Cloudant is not efficient in handling large amounts of binary data and can be expensive as a block store for larger assets such as images and videos. It is recommended to store only the attachment metadata in the IBM Cloudant document and write some extra code to upload the attachment to a suitable block store of your choice. You can find more information about attachments in IBM Cloudant in the provided document.

Additionally, you might be interested in IBM Cloud Object Storage, which is a highly available, durable, and secure platform for storing unstructured data, including media files such as images and PDFs. Objects in IBM Cloud Object Storage are organized into buckets and can be configured independently in terms of locations, resiliency, billing rates, security, and object lifecycle. All data stored in IBM Cloud Object Storage is encrypted, erasure-coded, and dispersed across three locations, contributing to a bucket's resiliency.

rewritten_query: What is the file size limit for attachments?
agent_response: Yes, there are file size limits in IBM Cloudant. The maximum size of each file that you can crawl by using a connector is different based on the deployment type. For managed deployments on IBM Cloud, premium plans can crawl files up to 50 MB, while other plans have a limit of 10 MB. For installed deployments on IBM Cloud Pak for Data, all data sources have a limit of 32 MB. Additionally, the size of each file that you can upload depends on your Discovery plan type. For Cloud Pak for Data, the limit is 50 MB per document, while Premium and Enterprise plans allow 50 MB and Plus (includes Trial) allows 10 MB. For more details, you can refer to the Maximum document size table.

rewritten_query: How do I get started with IBM Cloudant? Should I look through the cloud catalog?
agent_response: Yes, you can get started with IBM Cloudant by looking through the IBM Cloud catalog and selecting the IBM Cloudant service. Once you have created an instance of the service, you can start storing and managing your JSON documents in the cloud. You can also refer to the provided document "Getting started with IBM Cloudant" for more detailed instructions. Additionally, you can find SDKs for Java, Python, Go, and HTTP API, as well as the IBM Cloudant Dashboard to help you interact with your databases and refine your index and querying skills.
